I watch your vids with huge enjoyment. They are inspiring enough for me to want and go out and buy a lathe,  a belt drive sander, tools and the like. The one thing I don't have is the engineering background.  But that is ok. Your sheer skills and talent for reviving old equipment is exciting and mentally rewarding. You revive these items so that I don't have to, and thus it becomes so rewarding to see the finished item.  It would be easy to skip to the end and see the before and after result, but that isn't the point. Watching you make a new part is, for me, a joy to watch. We the viewers are then rewarded by the "eh voila" moment.  And it is ALWAYS superb. Then I think, I wish I could do that. But that is my envy of your excellent skills. Superb channel.

I love watching these restorations, but have one complaint.  As a teacher of machinists, I cringe when i see people file or polish on a lathe in the manner shown here - and elsewhere.  These operations are ALWAYS done left handed.  Never reach over the chuck to file or polish.  I've heard far too many horror stories of guys getting wrapped up in the chuck.  Any before someone says, "oh it's ok he has abre arms", that simply is not a good answer.  Other than that, I can't wait for the next one!  Keep up the good work.

This is a link: http://www.blowlampsociety.com/BN92.pdf  to a pdf w/similar torches as yours. It may help answer the lower fuel reservoir cover, and wick issue. Someone mentioned 'paraffin' also, and as I was researching the 'lower reservoir' issue, I found that it was the correct fuel for many of the lamps. Wettstein and Oerlikon are mentioned in this link, and look similar to your torch also. Hope this helps to fully complete the piece.


Also, theres an "iron" which attaches to a rod that goes through the hole on the top front end of your torch thats missing, which allows the iron to sit in the flame for soldering. Many of the torches I found were referred to as: blow "lamps" - "pressure lamps" - "torches." In many cases "lamps" is actually the proper name. This is another link to information which includes approx. date of mfg, and origin for many of the torches that were made:
http://blowlamp.co.uk/MY%20WEBS%20~%20Primus%20date%20&%20number%20codes%20-%20FOR_SERVER/primus_blowlamps_a%20brief%20history%20-%202nd%20attempt.htm#notes

Although these were primarily used for soldering, they were also used for removing paint from woodwork. Old paint had lead in it and in the smoke when it's burnt off. The lower reservoir does not have a cover. It's open to allow the fuel to flame up and over the upper main flame chamber (to pre-heat it). Once most of the fuel in the open reservoir has burned off (about 3-5 minutes), the upper main chamber/tube should be hot enough to use. Turn the knob to start the flame (it should self ignite). If it doesn't, just use a stone igniter or zippo/lighter. In about 1-2 minutes the main flame will go from orange to blue. That is when it's ready to use. Then adjust the knob to get the size flame you need. You can also open the knob a little bit during the preheating phase to help speed things up a bit. Btw, the above blow torch (from what I found after using Google) is actually a soldering iron (which can also be used as a blow torch). The holes in the top part of the body/casting is used to hold/lock in a soldering "tip". Kinda like this one. https://tinyurl.com/yc44yatv

The vinegar removes zinc from brass a little.  This is why some of it was more copper colored on the top part.  Extended acid contact is a harsh treatment.  In this case the part is thick and pressure low but be careful with it on anything like pressure fittings or water fittings.  But in any case this is another amazing job.

Many years ago, I bought a gas "jet engine" that ran on white gas. The thruster section, a empty CO2 bottle with a removable brass gas jet at the rear of the capsule was loaded with white gas. Just like your torch there was a gas prompter dish which was loaded with a wick soaked in white gas which was clipped onto the CO2 bottle with stiff wire that held it below the CO2 bottle. The "jet engine" was suspended from a string.  The prompter dish was lit which heated the gas in the CO2 bottle causing it to get hot, ignite and cause the bottle to spin. It was sold as a model engine, but was never installed on any of my model airplanes.

To make it complete you need to get wick material that fits into the up tube portion of the  start up pan on the bottom, and only enough to pull the small amount of fuel you place into the pan (just enough the soak the wick and not completely flood the pan) so it directs the flame up to the torch tip and does not send flame up at the valve assembly section from the main pan, that is what is causing the sputtering and unstable flame, too much heat in the rear valve assembly area.
